securization Financial Contracting and Market regulation recent work has
examined issues of the optim his recent work has designed has examined issues of the optimal design of SEC Securities
optimal compensation mechanisms regulation of insider trading and broker dealers Bank Capital regulation and
influence of information asymmetrics on corporate disclosures and investment welcome
Peter thanks uh first let me thank um you everyone here at the Stanford center
for for professional development it's a great opportunity to to be here and thank you for hosting this um and thanks
to all the participants for for joining in and I uh look forward to today's session I was asked to give a general

you to ask for investment advice you know what are interest rates going to do what do you think of this stock pick um
my cousin's a doctor and has more or less the same problem although he says the good thing is whatever advice he gives 90% of all ailments go away on
their own and he gets the credit unfortunately as a finance Professor when things go well people think they're
the Geniuses and only blame you when things uh go wrong so with that caveat
uh let me tell you a bit about investing in financial markets what the data shows and some important mistakes to avoid
much of what I'm going to say many of you have heard probably in some form before but you may not have fully come
to appreciate their implications I'm going to start um
oops I'm going to start with a picture uh that you've probably all seen in some form it's probably the most famous
picture in finance and that's the historical performance of different types of Investments what we're going to
do is go back in time to 1925 and imagine where our grandparents or greatr Grand parents investing on our
behalf um and so suppose we had $100 to invest at that time and we start with the most conservative investment
treasury bills if we put $100 in treasury bills at that time by 2012 it
would have grown to almost uh to a little over $2,000 now that seems impressive until
you think about what happened to prices during that time let's plot the Consumer Price Index over the same period and
you'll see that you'd need almost $1,300 today to have this the same purchasing power as $100 in
1925 so investing in t bills would have in increased your purchasing power but
less than doubled it okay let's suppose instead we invested in corporate bonds rather than government bonds if we look
at what happened to $100 investment in corporate bonds over the period we'll see it would have grown to over
$20,000 in other words uh about 10 times as much as we would have gotten in government
bonds let's take a look uh and compare now to stocks if we invest had invested
$100 in the S&P 500 which is a portfolio of the 500 largest stocks in the market
that $100 investment would have grown to about $275,000 again a more than 10x
improvement over what we had with corporate bonds finally let's look at an investment in small stocks $100 invested
in small stocks back in 1925 would have grown to over $2 million today and again
another 10x improvement over that investment in large stocks so this picture makes a pretty compelling case
for considering investing in the stock market but if you look at it closely you'll see it tells another and perhaps
even more important story what we might expect uh these Investments to rank in this way over shorter Horizons there's
no guarantee there's a great deal of risk involved okay so let's just take a
look at a couple of examples of that let's go back to imagine we were stock market and investors in 1929 if you had
invested in the stock market in 1929 that's that blue curve that you see here
um it would have taken until roughly the end of World War II before that
investment would have turned out better than just keeping your money uh underneath your mattress over that
period so uh quite a long Horizon you would had to wait to see some benefit from your
investment let's take another more recent example if we go to the stock market in 199 9 UM and again as this
picture shows we expect the stock market to outperform bonds but if you had switched to corporate Bonds in
1999 um that investment uh would have come out way ahead uh even a decade
later than where you are in the stock market over this period and it's only very recently in the past year that
we've started to see the stocks make gains relative to bonds um uh uh much
more recently one more example to take a look at is small stocks um suppose back
in the early 80s you had seen this graph up until that point in time and got convinced that small stocks were a great
investment opportunity if you had switched to small stocks in the early 1980s you would have been sorely
disappointed with that investment Choice over most of the next 30 years and it's only very recently that small stocks
have started to come back and make gains relative to larger stocks so as I said this picture is
really hiding a fair amount of uncertainty a fair amount of risk another way to understand that is to
take the same data and present it a bit uh differently let me provide you with a
histogram showing the frequency of different levels of annual returns for these different types of
Investments for example let's look at treasury bills um if we plot out uh the histogram
for treasury bills it looks like this and what you'll see is that most of the time uh you earn between 0 and 5%
investing in treasury bills some of the time between 5 and 10% and a few years you were able to earn between 10 and 15%
investing in treasury bills that was back in the early 80s when interest rates were quite high but overall a very tight
distribution not a lot of variability in the in the returns for treasury bills if I compare that to corporate bonds you
see a bit more spread out distribution um some years you actually lost some money in corporate bonds through
defaults or downgrades other years you might have made quite a bit more in corporate bonds compared to
treasuries applying the same data for stocks we see an even wider distribution here the annual returns range between
minus 50% to plus 50% and of course as we probably expect
small stocks are going to show the widest distribution of all the most volatile of these four investment
categories now we can measure the variability in terms of the standard deviation of these annual returns which
we refer to in finance as the assets volatility so volatility just another word for standard deviation of these
returns and and you can see that we have the same ranking as we saw in performance at least volatile being
treasury bills then corporate bonds then large stocks and then small
stocks now I can take both of those observations and put them together in
one figure like I show here um where on the vertical axis I've plotted the
historical average return for these different investment categories and on the horizontal axis I've plotted their
historical volatility and I've thrown at a couple of other Investments as well a port a worldwide portfolio of stocks
together with uh a midcap stock portfolio just so you can see how they align as well and what you can see
immediately in this picture is a tradeoff between risk and return and that's exactly what we should expect
because of their higher volatility for example to attract investors small stocks need to offer a higher average
return otherwise investors uh would invest in them another way of saying this is there's no free lunch in the
market if you want the higher return of stocks you're going to need to accept the risk that goes with it you're not getting something for nothing that
higher return is a reward for your willingness to take to take risk indeed if we draw a line in this
picture through uh treasury bills and the overall Market portfolio of the S&P
500 which we'll think of as a proxy for the for the broader Market we get what is called the security Market line and
this represents the risk and return opportunities that are available to investors by investing in the stock
market you can choose where you want to be on this line based upon your risk tolerance you can either invest more in
the stock market or more in treasuries to locate somewhat lower down on the line or somewhat higher up and even
leverage your position in the stock market if you want to if you're willing to take a lot of risk but hope for an
even higher expected return now that's the basically the menu that's available to you as an investor
and what I want to point out is that it's really hard to get above this line very few investment opportunities offer
sustained returns in the region up here above the line every now and then an
investment opportunity will appear that does seem to offer very high returns with very low risk but most often it
turns out to be an illusion uh the point I plotted here is actually uh made offs reported returns and uh we know what
happened there right uh it was really uh just a Ponzi scheme and so in general
it's very hard to find investment opportunities that are consistently above this
line now while it's really hard to get above this line um it's very easy to wind up below it if I plot individual
stock and investment portfolios you'll find something like this um so lots of individual investors
uh and portfolio strategies end up well below the security Market line that I plotted in other words individuals off
individual investors are often taking excess exessive risk or sacrificing return by making some basic errors and
by doing so we'll end up well below that security Market line that I just showed you and what I want to talk about today
is some of the errors that people make and how to avoid them how do we end up below this line and how do we avoid
doing that in particular what we'll see is that individuals often end up taking
excessive Risk by holding concentrated portfolios and trying to engage in Market timing they'll end up sacrificing
return by paying too much in fees and trading costs again trying to Market time and also exposing themselves to
adverse selection and I want to give you an insight into uh into each of those uh
so that you can understand uh how those errors can creep into your portfolio
Okay um so let's talk a little bit about how individuals investors behave and what are some of the common mistakes
that they make well the first one is very basic when we look at the portfolios of small investors uh what we
tend to find is that they're very underd Diversified many just hold one or two stocks in their
portfolio often it's the same stock of the company that they're working for I sometimes refer to this as the Enron
problem in illusion to the energy Trading Company that collapsed uh back around 2000 uh many of their employees
had most of their retirement Savings in Company stock and so what happened was they lost their jobs and their
retirement savings at the same time so in some sense being doubly uh undiversified um now it turns out that
you can cut your risk by more than half without sacrificing returns simply by
trying to spread your Investments out diversifying to different Industries different locals Etc spreading those
Investments around it's not too hard to get rid of more than half of the risk that you would take uh investing in the
stock market so that's one obvious implication I'm sure one that you've heard
before the other thing I want to mention is something we see in the pattern in the way individuals trade um when
investors buy stocks what we notice is that they tend to sell the stocks quickly when they go up uh whereas they
hold on to them uh when they fall now there are a couple of interesting things about that first of all it tends to be a
tax inefficient strategy um for tax purposes typically what you'd like to do
is defer realizing your gains so that you can delay paying taxes on your gains and accelerate realization of your
losses so you can get tax credits for any losses that you've incurred um and
so it doesn't make sense from a tax standpoint but it could make sense if investors know something if you know the
stocks they sell when they've gone up have finished their run their upward run and they're holding on to stocks that
have fallen because they expect them to turn around well if we look at the actual data uh this is what you find and
this is uh from a study by uh Odin and barber what they find is that if we look
at the stocks that investors sold um uh and looked at how they
performed over the rest of the year after investors sold them compared to the overall Market those stocks that
investors sold tended to continue going up relative to the market in other words uh investors seem to be selling the
winners too quickly and on the downside if we look at the losers that investors
are holding in their portfolio uh again relative to the market over the remainder of the Year those stocks seem
to continue to underperform the market and so they're hanging on to losers too long and so we see this asymmetry in
investor behavior is tax inefficient but even more importantly it's costing them in terms of the returns selling the
winners too quickly holding on to the losers uh longer than they
should the other thing that we see when we look at individual Traders is that individuals tend to trade a lot
especially men uh especially single men um why well you know most things in life
you add value by doing something and so presumably Traders have the same feeling
the annual turnover numbers by the way here represent the fraction of of shares in their portfolio traded in a single
year um now as I said you know people feel like they need to do something in order to add value to their portfolio
but guys you should only do something if you know something and if we look at performance it actually actually um
doesn't look so great so sorry to show you this uh but in fact just compared to
holding uh a basic uh market index fund most those individual investors are
underperforming on average and single men uh doing worst of all now that
picture doesn't tell the whole story because I haven't yet added in fees that they have to pay trading commissions and
the like when I add in fees uh here's the picture that you see uh once I've included in those trans actions costs so
a lot of trading activity but at least on average it's not working out so well for these individual
investors and that's a general pattern that you tend to see if I look more generally at investors and the frequency

partly uh because of exactly those fees and trading cost that they have to pay
um this uh bracket F the fifth uh uh Quant uh quintile here uh these are
those single men I was talking about you know Studies have looked at this group more closely and found that these folks
tend to you know be much more likely at doing other uh uh risky and impulsive
things get more speeding tickets and so forth uh uh than other folks on average so uh there seems to be some sensation
seeking uh Behavior going on there as well so hopefully they're enjoying doing all that trading um their portfolios
aren't necessarily benefiting from it okay let me tell you some other things obviously we've shown it doesn't
pay to trade randomly but you know suppose you do your homework you read The Wall Street Journal every day uh you
just trade when you learn some good or bad news uh about a company well like
that old adage you know buy the rumor sell the news by the time the news comes out it's the price is already adjusted
and there are no more gains to be had let's take just a quick look at that uh if we look at good news that's announced
in the Wall Street Journal uh for individual companies day zero here is the day that the announcement appears in
the Wall Street Journal and what you'll see is that you know once we're at that point if you were to buy the stock at that point in time there's really not uh
much upward movement that you should expect in the stock price going forward that it's already that the good news has
already been Incorporated in the stock price by the time it's in the newspaper if we look at bad news we see a very
similar phenomena uh Again by the time that bad news is out there it's again
already Incorporated in the stock price we're not going to make any money by uh selling the stock at that point in
time and so uh again just uh be worry of uh trading on Public Information the
evidence shows that most of there aren't many gains to be had from doing
so um okay so the the other um problem
with active trading in addition to just the transactions costs and tax consequences is that you're exposing
yourself to what we refer to as adverse selection and the point is that whenever you buy you're filling someone else's
sell order and only one of you can be beating the market so while you may think you're picking stocks it's
potentially more likely that you're the one being picked off by a more Savvy
investor um you know a recent Scandal just that kind of reminds us of this uh
happened with Goldman Sachs a Trader there uh fabri Tor as sometimes referred
to as fabulous Fab uh was selling mortgage cdos to the banks and had convinced the banks that they were the
ones picking the mortgage mortgages that were going into their portfolio when actually the mortgages that they were
getting had been picked had been handpicked by famous short seller John Paulson on the other side who made about
uh over a billion dollars on those on those trades and um uh when that was revealed uh Goldman
Sachs um uh suffered in terms of their reputation and so forth with their customers but the general point is a
good one whenever you're out there trading there's someone who's likely to be someone informed who's trading on the
other side and you've got to decide are you the one uh who's smarter than average or are they really trading
against you and and and picking you off in the process let me give you uh sort of a concrete example of this adverse
election problem uh in the context of IPOs you may be aware that most IPOs
tend to go up on the first day in fact if you look historically over time you'll see it's a pretty consistent
pattern that um ipo's go on average about 15% the first day uh there's an
upward jump in the stock price when they first start trading now that might suggest that we could make a lot of
money simply by investing $110,000 in every IPO that comes out if we look at you know roughly 100 IPOs per year if we
made $1,500 each one that's about $150,000 per year that we could make if we follow the strategy and could enjoy
those 15% returns well not so fast um it is true
that IPOs tend to go up on average by 15% uh but first of all they don't always go up so if you look at it some
of them go up by more than 15% but some actually fall in value um anybody remember Facebook right and Facebook did
not go up the first day it actually had a decline in value the first day um and so while the average return is 15%
there's actually some variability around that so let's just take kind of a an approximate distribution here of saying
about 80% of the time they go up and they go up on average of about 20% and about 20% of the time those IPOs fall on
the first day and may go down on average of about 5% now that still leads us to a 15% average return if we just do the
math here multiplying each row and then combining them you get about a 15% average return so why can't we make
money doing this well the problem is if we look at the allocation that you're going to get uh in the IPO you're not
going to be able to invest $110,000 in every IPO why is that well because the
very successful IPOs tend to be over subscribed and while you might put it in order for $10,000 $10,000 worth of the
stock your broker may only be able to deliver a much smaller amount say $500 worth of the stock It's Not Unusual for
very popular IPOs to be 20 times over subscribed that is there's 20 times the demand for the number of shares they
actually have outstanding and so you're going to get only some fraction of the amount that you requested on the other
hand the less popular IPOs the one where the price is likely to fall your broker is likely to come back and say you know
what I was able to fill most of your order I got you $8,000 worth uh of that IPO now of course we don't know which
are going to be the most popular ones up front and so if we now do the math and look at the allocation we actually get
multiplying again each row and adding up we'll see that we're not actually making any profit in this situation because
we're experien this adverse selection we're getting much less of the very successful IPOs and a much bigger all
allocation of the less successful ones the more informed Traders basically taking that profit not leaving anything
left for us um so again sort of this even though we know that the average
returns look good just a naive investment here uh would not pay
off one last uh piece of evidence I'll show you um some of you may be uh
familiar with the show Mad Money um and there's a recent study that looked at Mad Money recommendations and again
found kind of a similar pattern that is when they looked at Mad Money recommendations um uh for stocks where
there was news uh what they found was that news was already incorporated into the stock price and there were no real
further gains to be had if you traded on that mad money recommendation on the other hand if we looked at stocks for
which there was no news and mad money was making kind of an independent recommendation independent of any news
announcement first of all these tended to be smaller stocks but what you found is that people who bought into those
stocks um tend they tended to be overhyped initially and that over the
next uh several weeks that stock tended to fall and while there was overall a
persistent positive uptick in the stock price uh getting in with the crowd sort of hurting with a bunch of investors all
trying to get in uh meant you might be overpaying up front and actually losing a few percentage points uh over the next few
weeks on average as some of that hype dissipated Okay so we've talked a lot
about some of the the traps that individual investors fall into uh what about um uh professional investors and
you know mutual fund managers what does performance look like there um well let's take a look at that
uh next and here's uh here's an interesting picture if you look at mutual fund performance um what you'll
find for average mutual fund performance if we looked at actively managed funds is that they too tend to underperform
just a broader market index portfolio Okay on average by about half a percent
uh per year over all categories we also find that the underperformance is closely related uh with the fund fees
that is uh the higher the fees the fund charge uh the worse your performance so
in some sense you know the reverse of you get what you pay for here paying higher fees only got you uh worse
performance and um that's an interesting observation I think many investors aren't aware of that um you know simply
investing in uh a mutual fund at random or an average mutual fund is likely to be worse than investing in in a simple
uh market index now it doesn't mean it's impossible to beat the market um there
could be some funds that do beat the market but it does suggest that doing so is either likely to be luck or otherwise
based on something unsustainable or perhaps involve hidden risk or finally be something you know based on something
that's that's hard to copy that is a fund manager would need to have access to you know information that others
don't have or some unique investment opportunities um have special trading efficiencies that they can exploit or
some unique talent in interpreting the data now of of course this is what we H for is something in this last category
where it's really something sustainable but the real question is if the manager does have some unique talent like that
why would the fund manager give it away why would they give that benefit to their investors rather than charging for
it through their fees and in fact that's what we seem to find even those managers who do have uh talent and are able to
beat the market are charging more in fees than the amount by which they they
outperform um let me show you another picture that kind of highlights this if we look at institutional fund managers
these are fund managers who manage stock Investments for Pension funds endowments Etc and if we look at past performance
before they got hired say by the the pension fund that's hiring them their past performance does show them beating
the market on average by about 3% per year which is significant given that the
average institutional fund manager only beats the market by about 60 basis points per year uh that's that average
line I have in there as well um and so this is exactly what you'd expect um you
know Pension funds or hiring managers who are outperforming who look great relative to the average um so what do

we sh be we saw beforehand which suggests one of two things uh both
probably factors one is that that that past performance was in large part luck
and unlikely to be repeated and number two even if there was some component of skill these fund managers have now been

institutional uh fees are about 50 basis points per year so this amount by which
they're beating the market more or less is in line with the fees that they're charging suggesting very little of that
benefit is going to uh the ultimate
investors okay um let me give you uh I've talked a

least on average must always win relative to active investing okay um if
you think about the market and let's segregate into two types passive investors who simply hold the market

two to 5% relative to the overall market and that's just a simple math that there's no way to avoid
okay so on average the pool of act active investors must be underperforming
a simple Index Fund or passive strategy and the only way that some investors
might be beating the market is that other investors are in there in that active pool who are willing to lose to
the market okay and so you just want to make sure you're not one of those investors who's basically providing the

um let me uh look at one last uh phenomena which is an interesting one so
here we've talked a lot about the average fund manager the average institutional fund manager and so forth
um can we do better can we kind of look at past performance and try to find out
who is it that's got hot hands who's doing well in the market now who should I put my money with is there a way to

in particular can we use past performance to try to pick winning funds so let me just tell

let's take a look at the following so investment newsletters um investment newsletters
often provide advice on which stocks to invest in and so forth um there was a study that was done that looked at uh a

was the best performing investment newsletter from the prior year okay so
which investment newsletter had had the most outstanding uh returns and then we're going to follow that newsletter's

grown to about $500,000 it was a great decade for the stock market as we all know if you had
followed the best performing newsletter strategy $100,000 investment would have
grown to $70,000 okay not a very good performance
indeed and in some sense if we step back and think about it um we probably
shouldn't all that surprised so why do I say that well if you think about what
we're selecting on when we're finding the highest uh return investment
newsletter from the prior year what's the main thing we're probably SEL selecting on we might be selecting on
skill but we're most likely selecting on risk right how do you get to be an outlier well you did something really
risky and you got lucky and so we're probably selecting on newsletters who invested in very risky port p folios and
if we follow those newsletters in the coming year and they take similar risk there's no reason to expect that their
luck is going to go the same in the coming year as it did in the prior year so that's a really important
observation that whenever you're looking at past performance if you're just looking at Absolute returns you're in
some sense selecting on risk and probably selecting on risk much more than you're selecting on
skill this reminds me of a story of um my niece uh was taking taking uh an
economics class in middle school and they were doing um a stock market segment and each the idea was each
student was supposed to pick a portfolio and at the end of the month they would see whose portfolio did the best and
whoever did the best was going to win a prize I forget what it was it was tickets to some local concert that was
going to be happening or something like that and she was very interested in this and really wanted to win this prize and
so she came to me for advice and so you know against my better judgment I thought okay let me let me see if I can
help her here and so I asked her well there's a prize if you win you know what happens if you lose and she said well
there's no there's no penalty if you lose you know it's just kind of a fun thing for the winner you get these concert tickets and so forth and so I
said well if your only goal is to try and win you know the best strategy is let's find some really really risky
penny stocks and we're going to leverage the heck out of your portfolio and you know with basically
5050 chance you're going to get lucky and you're going to have astronomical returns and another 50% chance you're
going to get unlucky and lose everything but you don't care about how much you lose and so it took her a while to uh to
get this but in the end she sort of got the logic of it thought this was a great idea and so we found some stocks we leveraged it up and um all looked good
until a week later she came home from school with a note from the teacher uh in tears and apparently the teacher was
upset because she had demoralized the rest of the class um because her portfolio was doing so well no one else
felt like they could catch up and it kind of kind of ruined the spirit of the whole exercise and so uh we couldn't win
anyway in that sense so uh just something uh to keep in mind again when
we're look just looking at Absolute performance um uh fund managers have an
incentive to take extra risk just to look good and get that attention but you
don't want to be picking your funds based on risk so let me tell you something another more uh sensible
selection strategy that we might follow right and you know if we look at four
and Morning Star lots of services provide a ranking of mutual funds where
they don't just look at Absolute performance where they try to look at uh an assessment of risk in the past and uh
based upon both return and risk try to say well who's delivered good performance given the level of risk that
they were taking and so for example Forbes has an honor role of outstanding mutual funds and there are other uh uh

return in our recommendations um but how does that work out what's the persistence there
well there was a study a famous study looked at these honor roll funds um and said what if we invest each year in

are most highly ranked in the honor role and then follow those funds in the coming year um if we did that for a

13.6% that's a that's quite a nice return now it's a bit of an overestimate because I'm not counting sales loads and

forth if we look at the overall Market over the same 25-year period you would have found in the stock market about a

while uh that ranking is much more sensible there's still not a lot of persistence and not enough to overcome
the fees and other charges that you pay uh in these mutual funds it's very hard to predict the
winners let me just give you one last uh very specific story on this point and
this is the story of Bill Miller's leg Mason value trust mutual fund and Bill
Bill Miller was very famous in investment circles and uh let me tell you the story of why uh his fund started
in the mid1 1980s um in uh in early uh 90s uh really started to do
well with the fund he had about 700 million uh uh on assets in assets under management the early 90s and started to

Bill Miller started to become very famous as you know the mutual fund out there mutual fund manager out there with
